text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
in CNBC Americans call the economy the
top issue of election 2008 and both
presidential candidates agree on the
target voters the one sarah palin says
do some of the hardest work in america
who grow our food run our factories and
fight our wars that raises a question
for the general election can John McCain
prevail without offering more for those
voters pocketbooks McCain has joined
Barack Obama in expressing empathy for
the travails of ordinary workers and
calling for change yet the principle
elements of his economic agenda on taxes
trade regulation and health care follow
the philosophic outlines of a deeply
unpopular Bush administration in the new
immediate economic benefits each side
offers Obama has far-out bid as
Republican adversary he proposes a new
tax credit a five hundred dollars per
worker a new mortgage interest credit
valued at an average of five hundred
dollars for homeowners who don't now
itemize their tax deductions and a
college tuition subsidy of four thousand
dollars per year for students who
perform community service he'd wipe out
income taxes for senior citizens earning
less than fifty thousand dollars that's
on top of the unspecified health
insurance subsidies Obama would provide
for those who don't now have coverage
and an increase in the existing
dependent care tax credit that could
save eleven hundred dollar for a single
parent of two children who earns forty
thousand dollars by comparison McCain's
list of benefits is more modest he would
double the existing child exemption to
seven thousand dollars but most tax
filers wouldn't benefit because they
have no dependent children or have
income so modest but they don't owe
income taxes already McCain's largest
proposal is a new five-thousand-dollar
credit for buying health insurance but
for most workers who already have
employer-provided insurance that credit
would be offset by a new tax on those
employer-provided policies that doesn't
mean McCain can't attract blue-collar
swing votes in battleground states
there's a former war hero opposing a
relatively inexperienced Democrat who is
also the first african-american nominee
in American history he can appeal to
those voters on national security and
cultural values he can also revive
traditional Republican attacks against
tax-and-spend liberalism and trade
protectionism but some Republicans are
skeptical given the depth of Americans
economic anxiety as one advisor to
President Bush told me I don't see how
he can win
he doesn't talk about the number one
issue in every poll and say something
besides generic Republican dogma
